ygData.subject: Re: Behavior characterization for agents in complex interactive environments
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, I like your idea for characterizing behavior in dynamic and interactive environments, and I think it makes good sense.  I d be interested in seeing how

Peter, I like your idea for characterizing behavior in dynamic and
interact=
ive environments, and I think it makes good sense.  I'd be
interested in se=
eing how well it works. 

One issue may be that some individuals simply nev=
er encounter the
situations that others do.  Therefore, some of the behavio=
r
characterization will be blank.  How do you think such blank areas can
be=
 rectified when comparing two individuals?  For example, perhaps you
took a=
 right turn when you could, but I never encountered an
opportunity to turn =
right.  Do we consider this behavior different? 
(I am assuming we would ju=
st ignore that dimension of behavior, but
perhaps you have another idea)  I=
n general, I like your idea and think
it should be an effective general app=
roach.

It may also be possible to characterize behavior in more general
te=
rms.  Even though evaluation is inherently noisy, it is possible
that a gen=
eral characterization may filter out much noise.  For
example, perhaps some=
thing like counting how many door an individual
enters or how much food it =
eats could give a general sense of its
personality even though it would var=
y slightly in any given lifetime.

These are important issues if NS is to b=
e used directly in an
interactive/coevolutionary world, so it's good to thi=
nk about them.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar=
_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi all, 
> 
> I was thinking of how to characte=
rize behavior of an agent in a 
> complex dynamic world. As you all know, t=
he 2D maze world in the 
> demos is a static one. It doesn't interact with =
the agent. Thus it is 
> possible for Novelty Search to exploit the static =
environment and 
> develop behaviors that are not successful or meaningful =
on even 
> slightly different maze configurations. I don't say that NS does=
n't 
> find general solutions able to navigate most mazes. I mean that "bor=
n 
> to solve only this particular maze" solutions appear often. 
> 
> Furt=
her, what if I add more agents, in a realtime interavtive 
> environment li=
ke the one in NERO? While trying to generalize 
> everything I see in terms=
 of behavior characterization, it was 
> difficult to just say "the agent d=
oes this!" and use it as BC. It is 
> because the real world environment is=
 not static, it interacts with 
> the agent, so it becomes something like n=
oisy evaluation when I try 
> to evolve one. The same individual could appe=
ar more and less novel 
> every time. 
> 
> So one day, I was observing my =
dog.. Let's think of my dog as a 
> complex biological agent in a real worl=
d interactive environment.. If 
> you try to make a summary of its behavior=
, how can you do it? One may 
> suggest to put the dog in various situation=
s and observe its 
> reactions, finally collecting a summary of what it doe=
s in those 
> situations. While this seems like the solution, it is not. Be=
cause in 
> order to compare different dogs, you will have to put all of th=
em 
> through the same tests in order to avoid the noisy evaluation. And 
>=
 this brings us to a static environment again, because we know what 
> exac=
tly is going to happen to all agents, in order to see their 
> reactions. W=
hile realizing that, I arrived on a better idea that I am 
> going to talk =
about now. 
> 
> In a complex interactive world, a little is known what exa=
ctly can 
> happen to an agent. Further, the agent has a limited set of act=
ions 
> that it can take. A behavior characterization taking into account t=
he 
> actions only is not enough, because it is not known what happened to =

> the agent before that action. So one solution I came up with is this 
> =
one. You have a list of all possible and/or performed actions for the 
> BC=
. For each action, a summary or a more detailed list of situations 
> must =
exist. So basically let's say that we have a simple robot that 
> can go fo=
rward, fire a rocket and turn left/right. With rangefinger 
> sensors or wh=
atever. Instead of tracking only *what* it did during 
> its lifetime, the =
system now has to track also in what circumstances 
> the particular action=
 took place, and add that to the summary of 
> behavior. This can be the in=
puts at that particular timestep, for 
> example. Or the relative positions=
 of other agents that it may 
> interact with. 
> 
> Does it make sense? Su=
ppose you try to characterize a driver in a 
> city traffic conditions. Any=
thing can happen. But if you also track 
> what the driver *sees* in the pa=
rticular moments when he acts, in 
> addition to what actions he takes, it =
is a lot easier to distinguish 
> between different driving behaviors.
> 
>=
 I will be happy to hear your thoughts about this. Perhaps it is 
> nothing=
 new, but I didn't see any discussion about it. Though it is 
> an importan=
t issue about how to use Novelty Search for multi-agent, 
> coevolutionary,=
 and some real-world applicatons. 
> 
> Peter
>
